question: Question_05_(b)
statement:
Consider the curve given by

\begin{align*}\displaystyle y = f(x) = \frac{1}{x^{p}}\end{align*}

for $\displaystyle 1 \leq x \leq B$ where $\displaystyle p,B$ are
constants with $\displaystyle B > 1$ and $\displaystyle p > 0$.

(b) Compute the volume obtained by revolving the same region about the
\emph{x}-axis. (Later we will refer to this volume as V).
hints:
The volume \emph{V} obtained by rotating a function \emph{y=f(x)} around
the \emph{x}-axis (for $a \leq x \leq b$) is
$V = \int_{a}^{b} \pi [f(x)]^2 dx.$

We have

\begin{align*}f(x)^2=\frac{1}{x^{2p}}.\end{align*}

Are there any values of \emph{p} that makes this integral special
compared to other values?
